Name: Epoxiconazole
Description: (2S,3R)-epoxiconazole is the (2S,3R)-stereoisomer of 1-{[3-(2-chlorophenyl)-2-(4-fluorophenyl)oxiran-2-yl]methyl}-1H-1,2,4-triazole. It is an enantiomer of a (2R,3S)-epoxiconazole.

plant_translocations.content: The aim of this study was to assess the bioavailability of epoxiconazole (EPO) and difenoconazole (DIF) in rice plants by evaluating their uptake, translocation, and accumulation. The results showed that the concentration of DIF in the roots was approximately three times higher than EPO, and both accumulated mainly in the roots. In addition, EPO continued to be transported from stems to leaves, causing a rise in its concentration in leaves, whereas only a minimal amount of DIF was transported to the leaves. This phenomenon is mainly governed by their differing octanol-water partition coefficient. The effects of dissolved organic carbon (DOC) on the accumulation of EPO and DIF in the roots were similar to those of the freely dissolved concentration measured by OECAMs. Furthermore, the concentrations of EPO and DIF in the roots and OECAMs consistently decreased with increasing DOC levels. A significant linear relationship was also observed between the EPO and DIF concentrations in root and OECAMs, confirming the accuracy and usefulness of the OECAMs method in predicting the bioavailability of EPO and DIF in rice roots. Therefore, OECAMs show good potential for use as a passive sampler to evaluate the bioavailability of EPO and DIF.
plant_translocations.reference: Chen, Y., Liu, X., Zhou, Y., Zhang, L., Mao, L., Zhu, L., & Zheng, Y. (2023). Bioavailability evaluation of epoxiconazole and difenoconazole in rice and the influence of dissolved organic matter in reducing uptake and translocation. Chemosphere, 341, 140060.

method.Plant Grown Condition: The plant containers were placed in a climate chamber with a 16-hour day cycle at 25°C and an 8-hour night cycle at 20°C. The relative humidity was maintained at 60–70%, and the illumination intensity was set at 300 μmol/m^2s.
method.Chemical Preparation: Standard EPO and DIF (purity >99%) were dissolved in acetonitrile.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: EPO and DIF were applied to rice plants at a concentration of 1 mg/L for uptake and depuration experiments. One Oryza sativa embryogenic callus (OECAM) and 20 rice seedlings were placed into a glass container containing 1 liter of EPO and DIF nutrient solution. The pesticide concentration in the nutrient solution was set at 100 μg/L. The relative humidity was maintained at 60–70%, and the illumination intensity was set at 300 μmol/m^2s.
method.Other Information: The experiments were conducted in triplicate, including control treatments.

plant_translocations.content: Brown root rot disease (BRRD), caused by Phellinus noxius, is a significant tree disease in tropical and subtropical regions. To enhance the chemical control of BRRD and prevent the emergence of fungicide resistance in P. noxius, this study examined the control efficacy and systemic activity of fungicides with various modes of action. Fourteen fungicides with different modes of action were tested for their inhibitory effects on 39 P. noxius isolates from multiple regions. Cyproconazole, epoxiconazole, and tebuconazole (target-site G1) exhibited colony growth inhibition of P. noxius by 99.9% to 100% at 10 ppm and 97.7% to 99.8% at 1 ppm. Another effective fungicide was cyprodinil + fludioxonil (target-site D1 + E2), which showed growth inhibition of 96.9% at 10 ppm and 88.6% at 1 ppm. Acropetal translocation of six selected fungicides was evaluated in bishop wood (Bischofia javanica) seedlings, with cyproconazole and tebuconazole being the most efficiently absorbed by roots and transported acropetally. Greenhouse experiments indicated that cyproconazole, tebuconazole, and epoxiconazole have slightly higher potential for controlling BRRD compared to mepronil, prochloraz, and cyprodinil + fludioxonil. Since all tested fungicides lacked basipetal translocation, soil drenching should be considered over trunk injection for their use in BRRD control.
plant_translocations.reference: Liao, T. Z., Chen, Y. H., Tsai, J. N., Chao, C., Huang, T. P., Hong, C. F., ... & Chung, C. L. (2023). Translocation of fungicides and their efficacy in controlling Phellinus noxius, the cause of brown root rot disease. Plant Disease, 107(7), 2039-2053.

method.Test Plant: Bischofia javanica (bishop wood seedlings), 6-12 months old used due to abundant roots, tender tissues, high susceptibility
method.Plant Grown Condition: Maintained at 35°C day/30°C night, 55-95% RH in phytotron. Under natural light. Leaves trimmed to 3-5 trifoliate leaves per plant before assays
method.Chemical Preparation: Root immersion - 100 ppm solutions of fungicides. Stem injection - Stock solutions ranging 75,000-625,000 ppm injected at 3 μL
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Acropetal - 5 root tips immersed in 50 mL fungicide solution. Bidirectional - 3 μL fungicide stock injected into stem
method.Other Information: Sampling at 7 and 21 days after treatment. Plant dissected into 5 cm segments (roots, stems, leaves). Fungicide concentrations measured by LC/GC-MS/MS. 2 independent trials with 6 plants per treatment (3 per timepoint)

plant_translocations.content: The study investigates the absorption and transmission behaviors of five fungicides (tricyclazole, thifluzamide, hexaconazole, epoxiconazole, azoxystrobin) in rice seedlings to improve pesticide utilization. Foliage spray, the most common method, has drawbacks such as evaporation and drift. By studying pesticide absorption and conductivity and selecting suitable pesticides for root application, the adverse effects of environmental factors on pesticide ingredients can be reduced. The results suggest that tricyclazole is best suited for root application, showing superior upward transmission in rice seedlings compared to the other fungicides. This research provides guidance for pesticide selection for root application and contributes to the scientific use of pesticides.
plant_translocations.reference: Shuojia, Z. H. A. N. G., Chaojie, W. A. N. G., Bo, X. U., Gangchao, R. A. N., Lidong, C. A. O., Chong, C. A. O., ... & Pengyue, Z. H. A. O. (2022). Study on uptake and translocation of five fungicides in rice. Chinese Journal of Pesticide Science, 24(4), 752-761.

method.Apply Location: Root application (both hydroponic and soil-grown conditions)
method.Plant Grown Condition: Rice seeds were germinated, and seedlings were transplanted into either hydroponic nutrient solution or soil-based growth medium. Treatments were applied when seedlings reached the three-leaf one-heart stage.
method.Chemical Preparation: 96% tricyclazole, 96% thifluzamide, 96% hexaconazole, 95% epoxiconazole, and 98% azoxystrobin technical grade compounds were used to prepare suspensions. Various adjuvants like dispersants, emulsifiers, thickeners, defoamers, and preservatives were also used in formulation development.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: Fungicide suspension concentrations of 100 mg/kg tricyclazole, 30 mg/kg thifluzamide, 30 mg/kg epoxiconazole, 20 mg/kg hexaconazole, and 60 mg/kg azoxystrobin were used.
method.Other Information: Rice samples were collected at 4 hours, and 1, 2, 3, 5, 7, 10, and 14 days after treatment.
